awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Scalable High Performance Computing System in Support of the Lattice Light-sheet Microscope for Real-time Three-dimensional Imaging of Living Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, developing a scalable high performance computational system, aims to support the acquisition, processing, and dissemination of data collected by the recently constructed Lattice Light-Sheet Microscope (LLSM).  Developed in collaboration between SDSMT, the University of South Dakota (USD), and South Dakota State University (SDSU), the instrument contributes to multiple proposed fluorescence imaging research projects, especially those in conjunction with the statewide Biochemical Spatiotemporal NeTwork Resource (BioSNTR) collaboration. The unified implementation allows investigators to access and apply any set of algorithms to any set of on-line imagery, independent of where the data resides and without requiring data conversion before processing. The power of the LLSM lies in its ability to capture high-speed three-dimensional (3-D) data constructed from wide-field fluorescence images, resulting in real-time volumetric imaging of living cells at sub-wavelength spatial resolution. To effectively utilize the capabilities of this advanced microscopy technique, significant computational hardware and software solutions must be developed to address the specific needs of this ultra-wide bandwidth system. The instrumentation also includes a web-portal design to allow geographically distant researchers seamless access to large volumes of fluorescence imagery. The instrumentation enables important studies that could contribute to the fundamental understanding of signaling processes in diverse biological systems and support the development of future bio-technologies, including improved bio-materials, improved understanding of cell signaling, and improved understanding of drought-tolerant plant species.

The instrumentation supports the need to dynamically visualize the evolution of fluorescently labeled markers within cellular and sub-cellular compartments of biological systems to inform bioinformatics studies and systems biology approaches towards the understanding and discovery of regulatory networks in biological systems, and to reveal the architecture of important biological systems studied with the LLSM. This project serves as the nexus for collaborative science undertaken by a diverse group of physicists, computer scientists, biologists, and chemical engineers with broad scientific, educational, and societal impacts. Methods for 3-D volumetric fluorescence imaging within cellular and sub-cellular compartments of animal and plant biological systems are necessary to extend current understanding of living systems. The impetus for the instrument resides in the need to tightly couple initial and subsequent bioimage informatics processing with the LLSM instrument itself, providing investigators with transparent and seamless access to the instrument, data, and appropriate processing techniques. Furthermore, the proposal emphasizes the significant effort needed to both collect and develop the appropriate techniques needed for this bioimage informatics initiative.

por.por_cntn:
A scalable, high-performance computational system was developed to support the acquisition, processing, and dissemination of data collected by the lattice light-sheet microscope (LLSM) constructed at the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM&T).

The power of the LLSM lies in its ability to capture high-speed three-dimensional (3-D) data constructed from wide-field fluorescence images, resulting in real-time volumetric imaging of living cells at sub-wavelength spatial resolution. Prior to its use in any bioinformatic approaches, the LLSM-generated image data must be post-processed and reduced to the key features provided by the specimens and their specific fluorescent preparation. These features must first be detected by image processing techniques and then further quantified as key parameters for analytical modeling.

The developed instrumentation supports the need to dynamically visualize the evolution of fluorescently labeled markers within cellular and sub-cellular compartments of biological systems, to inform bioinformatic studies and systems biology approaches towards the understanding and discovery of regulatory networks in biological systems, and to reveal the nanoscale architecture of important biological systems studied with the LLSM. The impetus for the proposed instrument is the need to tightly couple this initial and subsequent bioimage informatics processing of the resulting massive volumetric image datasets with the LLSM instrument itself, providing investigators with transparent and seamless access to the instrument, data, and appropriate processing techniques.  The unified implementation allows investigators to access and apply any set of algorithms to any set of on-line imagery.

Consistent with the proposal, major activities completed during the funding period include:

  • Acquisition, installation of a data appliance and storage server,
  • Development and integration of data transfer technology
  • Design, acquisition, installation of an HPC array
  • Integration of LLSM with HPC hardware
  • Basic data acquisition automation
  • Collection of existing analytic tools
  • Optimization for GP-GPU
  • Master service framework design
  • Remote access design
  • Integration of analytic tools w/ master service framework
  • Integration of developed instrument with the University of South Dakota (USD) and South Dakota State University (SDSU) for transparent data transfer and processing

The instrument was developed in collaboration with the University of South Dakota (USD), and South Dakota State University (SDSU) and contributes to multiple proposed fluorescence imaging research projects, especially those in conjunction with the statewide Biochemical Spatiotemporal NeTwork Resource (BioSNTR) collaboration. The developed instrumentation enables important studies that contribute to the fundamental understanding of signaling processes in diverse biological systems and supports the development of future biotechnologies, including improved biomaterials, improved understanding of cell signaling, and improved medical therapies.

The primary impact of this project on teaching and educational experiences is the training opportunities for using both the LLSM and the project HPC resources. The project HPC is specifically enabling advanced volumetric microscopy thus directly supporting student training in the use of this (LLSM) and other (PALM, STORM, AFM) microscopy techniques.
In addition, the design, construction, and use of advanced project HPC resources provides another training opportunity to these same students. Along with this, several Nano (709, 711, 713) courses utilize the remote desktop feature of the designed system to process large datasets as part of the coursework.

Six PhD graduate students and one post-doctoral researcher/research assistant professor have been trained on the system and gained enough mastery to have produced now two major publications (Nature Communications Quinn, et al. 2021, Nurmalasari, et al. 2023 Metallomics), another major preprint (submitted to Cell Reports) and five dissertations (Kota, Nurmalasari, Meyerink, Kang, Quinn). Another major preprint is currently being finished.

In support of the NSF CC* network design grant as a collaboration between the USD, SDSM&T, and Black Hills State University (BHSU), the LLSM and its dedicated HPC have become a main data source for testing the improved infrastructure. The CC* and MRI awards have allowed for full 100 Gbps connectivity to the LLSM and HPC with the 100 GbE network switches now in place. All major components of the intended system design are in place, with the ability to remotely access all data from the LLSM becoming a central design feature. The remote desktop processing model, enabled by the award, was further refined for use during the ongoing COVID pandemic and is critical to our sustained research efforts.

This system bridges the gap between a laboratory instrument, the LLSM, and information systems for data accessibility. It also represents a paradigm for scientific instrumentation, data collaboration, and availability. During the COVID-19 pandemic, this project enabled a robust continuation of imaging research at SDSM&T. This includes development of a web-based volumetric viewer for advanced microscopy accessible at the website http://minesbioimaging.glitch.me/.  The viewer utilizes recent compression techniques and web browser rendering to allow interaction with 4- and 5-dimensions that initially comprise nearly a terabyte of data. The data size is reduced by several orders of magnitude through pre-processing and compression before transmission and rendering.
